editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

IN the yeare 1647. Wee being Accu≈øed by many, as if we were Patrons of Liberty to ≈øin, and as if we denied Magi≈øtracy and Propriety in ones E≈øtate; and as if we owned Polygamy: We were enforced to Vindicate our ≈øelves in our Declaration then Agreed unto by our joynt Con≈øent, Printed for H. Overton neare the Exchange. and Publi≈øhed then in our Names, concerning tho≈øe foure Particulars charged upon us. Wherein we not onely A≈ø≈øerted the Contrary: but have al≈øo Declared, from the Holy Scriptures, The Rule and Standard for Faith and Obedience, what Liberty, and what Community is owned, and Di≈øclaimed therein. Which accordingly we ≈øtill owne, or Di≈øclaime: and what Nece≈ø≈øity there is of Magi≈øtracy, and what Obedience is due unto them in their places, as to an Ordinance of God. And how≈øoever Polygamy was practi≈øed in the Old Te≈øtament; that yet it is clearly Evinced in the New Te≈øtament, to be unlawfull.

Our Stating the before≈øaid Ca≈øes, and our Evidencing of what is the Truth therein, by clear Scriptures, and by Grounds deduced thence, we doe ≈øtill fully Adhere unto: How≈øoever ≈øome or other of the Scandals before≈øaid, ≈øome formerly, and ≈øome of late, have ≈ølanderou≈øly laid to our charge.

And now whereas of late yeares, the wi≈øe Providence of our God hath ≈øo Ordered it, that ≈øuch readine≈ø≈øe and chearfulne≈ø≈øe of many Chri≈øtians, that are Tearmed Independents, in their Adhering to the Parliament, even from the beginning of the late warres unto this day: and ≈øuch faithfulne≈ø≈øe and diligence hath been expre≈ø≈øed by many of them, in the State; and in the Armie, as well under the Earle of E≈ø≈øex, and the Lord Fairfax, as under the Pre≈øent Captaine Generall, the Lord Cromwell; that hereby many of them have been judged worthy of Offices and Places of Tru≈øt and Preferment, as well in England, as in Wales & Ireland. And whereas this hath occa≈øioned (though cau≈øle≈øly,) the Envy of many again≈øt them: and many have fal≈øly ≈øaid, That they ≈øeek to get all ≈øuch places into their own hands, and to exclude all others from them. (Which expre≈ø≈øions, though grievous to us, we did beare, as part of the Reproaches for Chri≈øt, and his Truth.)

And whereas now of late, when ≈øome have Objected again≈øt us a Booke or two, lately Publi≈øhed, The one called, A Modell of a New Repre≈øentative: The other called, A Cry‚ÄîWith ≈øome Cautions touching the Election of a New Repre≈øentative; as if tho≈øe Bookes were Publi≈øhed by us: So that we are Charged to profe≈ø≈øe therein, that which we had di≈øowned.

We are hereby Againe enforced, thus to come forth in Publicke in our ju≈øt and nece≈ø≈øary Vindication; lea≈øt if now wee ≈øhould be altogether ≈øilent, we ≈øhould indeed ≈øeeme to be deeply guilty therein. A Crime that we doe utterly dete≈øt and abhorre, as injurious to many: And with one Con≈øent wee doe thus Declare, as in the Pre≈øence of the Almighty, who is the Searcher of all hearts, before whom the Wicked and Deceitfull ≈øhall be confounded at the Day of Judgement.
Fir≈øt, That none of us did ≈øo much as know of the making of any ≈øuch Bookes, untill they were Printed and Publi≈øhed.

Secondly, That as thus we were farre from appointing or approving of, or Con≈øenting unto the ≈øaid Bookes before the Publi≈øhing of them; So neither did we, nor doe we Con≈øent to,
or approve of ≈øuch ∆≤nju≈øt Limitations, as appeare to be implyed in the CRY pag. 9. (Though that Cryers good intent towards all that feare God, be well ≈øet forth therein, pag. 5, 6, 7.) But are more fully expre≈ø≈øed by Quere's in the MODEL'S Xth, XI, XII, and XIIIth Quere's, Namely, That the Per≈øons to be Cho≈øen, and the Per≈øons to be Choo≈øers of the New Repre≈øentative, ≈øhould be limitted to the Gathered-Congregationall-Churches; [Here-in that MODEL is more like a Je≈øuiticall Device, to bring an Odium upon us all; then to be any Act of ours.]

Now that we may not be wanting (what in us is,) to cleare the Truth from Scripture Grounds, and to manife≈øt our ≈øen≈øe thereof, Touching Civill Governors, and the Choice of them, We mu≈øt premi≈øe Two Propo≈øitions, from the Holy Scriptures.

div.head: I. The Former Propo≈øition is this.

p.hi: That all People in Every Nation as well Members of Churches, as others, ought for Con≈øcience ≈øake, to Honor ≈øuch, as by the wi≈øe Di≈øpo≈øing Providence of God, are their Pre≈øent Rulers; and are to ≈øubmit to the Civill Commands, not onely of ≈øuch Rulers as are faithfull, but even to Infidels.

div.p:
Thus the Apo≈øtle Paul Commands us from the Lord, Rom. 13.1. to 8. ver≈ø. (with 1 Cor. 14.37.) Let every ≈øoule be ≈øubject to higher Powers. For there is no Power, but of God, &c. And thus the Apo≈øtle Peter al≈øo, in 1 Pet. 2.13. Submit your ≈øelves to every Ordinance of Man for the Lords ≈øake: Whether it be unto King as ≈øupream; or unto Governours. Thus they wrote, when all the Rulers Generally were Infidels. And Note; The Chiefe in Rule or Government, in what Political State ≈øoever, are ≈øtiled King in the Scripture phra≈øe; though he were not a King, according to our Vulgar expre≈ø≈øion. Thus Mo≈øes, that Judged I≈ørael, is called King in Je≈øurun, in Deut. 33.5. And when its ≈øaid, There was then no King in I≈ørael, it intends, there was then no Judge in I≈ørael; Thus Jud. 17.6. & Jud. 18.1. & 19.1. & 21.25. And thus in Rev. 17.9, 10. The 7 Heads are 7 Mountaines;-And they are 7 Kings: Five are fallen, (-&) one is, & the other is yet to come.-11 And the Bea≈øt-is the Eighth, and is of the ≈øeven; and goeth into Perdition. 12 And the ten Hornesare ten Kings. 16 They ≈øhall hate the Whore, and make her De≈øolate. The meaning ≈øeems
to be this; That City, which before Johns time, had had five ≈øorts of chiefe Rulers fallen, and had another ≈øort, the ≈øixt, then, viz. Cae≈øars. The ≈øeventh, the Pope, was to come; who al≈øo is the Eight, (by his Exerci≈øing of ≈øo great power; fir≈øt Eccle≈øia≈øtically, and then Civilly al≈øo;) That ≈øame City is the City ≈øpoken of in Rev. 17. Now that Rome had then had 5 ≈øorts of chiefe Rulers fallen, and that Cae≈øars ruled in Johns time, is Evident by Hi≈øtorians: So that Cornelius Tacitus, a Heathen, (that lived in Johns time,) in the very beginning of his Annales, thus reckons them up; In the City Rome at fir≈øt were Kings; then (2) Libertie & (two) Con≈øuls. 3. (one) Dictator (added to them.) (4) Decemviri. (5) Tribuni [plebis; [that is, the Government by Ten. And then by Three.] (6) the Power fell to Cae≈øar. And as for the Ten Kings that ≈øhould hate the Whore, be it generally expounded to include England, and the Netherlands, as well as others that for≈øake Rome. Thus by Kings, in Rom. 13. 1 Pet. 2. Rev. 17. We are to under≈øtand ≈øuch, as are Chiefe in Rule, in any Nation.

Rulers, and Laws, are for the Nations good. This Salus Populi is the End, and to be mo≈øt aymed at, and ≈øought after. When tho≈øe of the Netherlands, by the Spani≈øh King, were Tyrannized over, the States ca≈øt off the Tyrant, and have Governed ≈øince. And by the Army, (which was empowred by the Authority of the Nation to their utmo≈øt to ≈øeek for the End before≈øaid) there hath been ≈øuch ≈øubduing of Enemies and Ob≈øtacles, as that by the wi≈øe Providence of God, we are now reduced to a Common-wealth, wherein the Rulers, are now to be Honoured. div.head: II. The Second Propo≈øition is this;
